html.p: Although the system makes installing other software very easy, the Zero Install system itself still requires some work to install. You'll also need to have a few other things installed first (libxml to parse the XML index files, wget to download archives, tar and gzip to extract them, and GPG to check they are correctly signed). Most systems will have these installed already, although you may be missing the header files for libxml (libxml-dev).

div.p: This software is still under development and has not yet been carefully audited. Please do not run it on public machines (eg, in a school) where malicious users could exploit bugs in it. Please let me know if you find any problems. You could also install it under User Mode Linux if you want to test the kernel module in safety, although there have been no bugs discovered in the last few versions.

html.p: The Zero Install system requires a small Linux kernel module to provide the /uri/0install directory. Like all kernel modules, you must compile this using the actual kernel headers for the kernel you're actually running. The easiest way to ensure this is to have compiled your own kernel (eg, from kernel.org) and be running that. There are plenty of guides on the net if you don't feel confident about compiling your own kernel. For example, The Very Verbose Guide to Updating and Compiling Your Debian Kernel (which isn't very Debian specific, despite the name) and Compiling the Linux Kernel.
Only Linux 2.4 series kernels are currently supported, not the 2.5 series. If you want to port the (small) module to other kernels (or BSD, MacOS X, etc) please get in touch.

div.p: Joachim Kupke has created Debian packages for Zero Install.
However, version 0.1.11 is rather old and buggy, so I strongly suggest installing from the source tarballs below instead.
